Q: How does Marcus describe the proper response to insults?
ExpA: They harm the insulter not you remain rational
A:
Marcus advises responding to insults with kindness, forbearance, and meek correction rather than anger or ostentation. Be loving even to those who hate you; point out their error ingenuously and meekly, avoiding reproach or showing off your patience. Keep your temper, state only what concerns the case (not your own feelings), remember the offender harms himself and therefore deserves pity not wrath, correct with tact and gentleness, and refuse to become like them — “the best kind of revenge is, not to become like unto them.”

The mysterious book is "The King in Yellow".

Q: What effect does reading the play have on its readers?
A: Reading the play profoundly unsettles and obsesses its readers: it drives intense emotions (terror, joy, weeping, laughing, trembling), leaves a lingering horror and inability to forget Carcosa, and can even alter a reader’s character (making him active, energetic, temperate, and ambitious); readers who try to stop often find themselves compelled to continue.

on the hearth in the firelight. If I had not caught a glimpse of the

contrary it had changed my whole character for the better. From a lazy
young man about town, I had become active, energetic, temperate, and
above all—oh, above all else—ambitious. There was only one thing
which troubled me, I laughed at my own uneasiness, and yet it troubled
me.

Q: What was the primary purpose of the Federalist Papers?
ExpA: To advocate for ratification of the U.S. Constitution
A: The primary purpose of the Federalist Papers (as shown in these excerpts) was to explain and defend the proposed new Constitution and to persuade the people—particularly the people of New York—to adopt it by addressing objections, showing the insufficiency of the present Confederation, and describing the benefits of Union.

Q: What danger does Paper No. 10 warn against?
A: Paper No. 10 warns against dangers from dissensions between the States and from domestic factions and convulsions; it also expresses concern that State governments might sap the foundations of the Union.
